@woggastweet @orbawalsh @JacobYoungMP @AndrewRosindell You may not realise, Switzerland is not a member of the EU, and never will be.

@AlexMacca01 I used to work in Munich, Germany have a very complient nation, especially the elderly, they do have great hospitals, had a slightly extra capacity for ICU which made all the difference, have less people in hospital for preventable diseases and very expensive healthcare.
@FelicityM @gt2andy @JacobYoungMP @johnsweeneyroar @AndrewRosindell Switzerland has had nearly 3 X the cases we have.

@FelicityM @JacobYoungMP @johnsweeneyroar @AndrewRosindell I lived in Zermatt for 13 years, the Swiss know exactly what's happening, they were completely taken over by the virus a few weeks back before a strict lockdown, the same shortages, the same issues, no one was prepared for this.
@WestminsterWAG @pigsyspark I've been through them and they are truly horrific.

William Capes started to trade in Manchester in 1826, during the reign of George IV, the face of our logo. During all the years since, the company has weathered depressions and recessions, countless conflicts and 2 world wars - only closing during WW2 when directly hit by a bomb.

2020 is our 194th year of serving the people of Manchester and surrounds and is Michael Perry's 60th Anniversary with the company. Today (24th March), we have sadly had to close our doors in accordance with the government's announcement.

I think he would be absolutely delighted that today, 100 years after the setting up of the Leach Pottery, the Japanese PM, is able to visit Carbis Bay, the place where Leach had his family home, and St Ives, the home of the Leach Pottery.

David Kendall, grandson of Bernard Leach
between East and West.

St Ives is the place where my grandfather Bernard Leach, and his great friend, Hamada Shoji, set up the now world-famous Leach Pottery, in 1920
Leach maintained an enduring connection and friendship with Japan and its people, throughout his life, seeing himself as a ‘courier’...

On behalf of the Bernard Leach family, I would like to extend a very warm welcome to His Excellency, Yoshihide Suga, Japanese Prime Minister, and his delegation, on the occasion of his visit to St Ives, Cornwall for the 2021 G7 summit.
@G7 @CornwallCouncil @GOVUK @JapanGov https://t.co/VM8X30AJsu

📸: Nova Scotia Archives, The Clarion newspaper "Miss Viola Desmond Takes Action", 1946

In 2010, Lieutenant-Governor Mayann Francis issued Desmond a free pardon. In December 2016, the Bank of Canada announced that Viola Desmond would be the first Canadian woman to be featured by herself on the face of a banknote — the $10 note released on November 19, 2018.
Desmond’s courageous refusal to accept an act of racial discrimination provided inspiration to generations of Black persons in Nova Scotia and in the rest of Canada.

She was arrested, jailed overnight and convicted without legal representation for an obscure tax offence. Despite efforts from the Nova Scotian Black community to assist her appeal, Viola Desmond was unable to remove the charges against her and went unpardoned in her lifetime.

Desmond built a career and business as a beautician and was a mentor to young Black women in Nova Scotia. In 1946, she challenged racial discrimination by refusing to leave the segregated "Whites-Only" section of the Roseland Theatre in New Glasgow, Nova Scotia.

These bronze #coins are known as #DolphinMoney and are from ancient Olbia. There was a large population of dolphins in the  area at the time and they must have been well-loved by locals to have them represented in their #coinage.

#Cash was a type of #coin of China & East Asia, used from the 4th century BC-20th century AD, characterised by their round shape & square hole. 1000 year old #CashCoins produced during the Northern Song dynasty continued to circulate as valid #currency into the 20th century. https://t.co/qDJCq9hlqg

#KeichoKoban had been issued since 1601 & was currency by table having one Ryo value per one #Koban. This early Koban shows the chisel marks in 5 columns which are shallow & close together, indicative of the fine crenelation associated with early Kobans. https://t.co/4Fo4q9Rim9 https://t.co/Nvbuo0Jg9c
